subdebateinfo.title: Senior Australian of the Year Award

talk.start.para: —Thank you very much for this opportunity to speak, Mr Deputy Speaker. For a moment I thought I had not acknowledged you in the polite and proper manner. I am glad to hear that I was acknowledged.

speech.para: I attended this morning the launch by the minister, Bronwyn Bishop, of a very important program in the International Year of Older Persons 1999: the Senior Australian of the Year Award. I was very pleased to see that launch. It really instils in me and many others a sense of the great contributions that our senior citizens make. The fact of our demographics is that we are getting to be an older population. At the moment there are one in eight older Australians who are in the work force. There are now 2.2 million people aged 65 years and over living in Australia, and by the year 2016 there will be 3.6 million people in this demographic age group. It is also estimated that, by the year 2036, people over the age of 80 will make up 6.2 per cent of the population.

I have also been on a committee that dealt with mature age employment issues. The number of contributions that older people make in the community, in volunteer work and also in mentoring programs, cannot be ignored.

Why do we need to have an award and a program such as this? A lot of people do take our older generation for granted. I had the wonderful privilege of growing up in a family where my parents came to this country from southern Europe. I also had the wonderful opportunity of having a very close relationship with my grandmother and grandfather. I learned much from them. In my day-to-day life as well I have had the privilege of having some wonderful older people as mentors not only in a business sense but also in a political environment. I must say that it is absolutely terrific to have someone to go to. There is nothing like age and wisdom, as they say.

The reason these awards have been initiated in the first place is that they encourage mutual responsibility between the community and senior Australians. They recognise a significant contribution of older Australians to communities and families. They build partnerships involving government, business and the community to better meet the needs of Australians. They also improve younger people's understanding of older Australians and promote greater responsibility by families and individuals.

I have a fairly active older constituency in my electorate of Petrie: 30 per cent is over age 65. I see the same people in the community organisations that I go out to every day; they do outstanding work in my community. I am absolutely overawed by their energy, responsiveness and their sense of community. Organisations like Meals-on-Wheels, War Widows and University of the Third Age would not be as active or as well run if it were not for the individuals concerned.

I would also like to say that this is a very open process. Any member of the public is welcome to submit a nomination for the Commonwealth government Senior Australian of the Year Award. The person nominated for this award can be an Australian citizen. There is no formal age limit, so that is pretty good. The Commonwealth government Senior Australian of the Year is for those over the age of 65. He or she has to be a person of exceptional achievement who has made a significant contribution to the welfare of the nation.

These particular kits have been sent out to all electorates. I welcome and encourage all the members in the Main Committee to participate in this terrific program. Nominations will be accepted by any member of the public. The award is complemented by a separate Commonwealth recognition award for senior Australians, which recognises people who have made a significant contribution to their local community and it is coordinated through their federal MPs. This will hopefully be an ongoing national award, managed by the National Australia Day Council. I commend this award to the House.

talk.start.para: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Calwell, I will say that I mentioned to the honourable member for Robertson that the Deputy Chairs have been reminded by the Deputy Speaker to remind members that, when they pass in front of the chair, they should acknowledge the chair. The honourable member for Robertson was reminded a few moments ago; the honourable member for Calwell did exactly the same thing when he entered the chamber. I remind him of his obligation. I now call on him to speak.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I apologise. I always do that in the House; I will do so here as well.

speech.para: I wish to raise a very serious matter concerning the rebellion that occurred at the Maribyrnong Detention Centre on 22 July of this year and certain aspects of that issue. The detainees in the centre are, of course, asylum seekers; they are not people who have committed any crime. Nevertheless, because of the conditions in that centre and the development of many grievances over a period, there was a rebellion. The department of immigration advised that, as a result of that rebellion, the internal part of the centre was totally destroyed, including a general trashing of the centre—destruction of televisions, videos, computers, furniture, and the like.

One would have thought that this was a very serious event and that it would have been investigated. Instead, what happened was that the department of immigration tried to keep quiet the events that occurred on that day. It was only when Mr Nacer Benbrika, the president of the Algerian community of Victoria, came to see me that the matter was brought to my attention. That was seven days after the event.

Mr Benbrika had certain allegations to make about the events of that day. He asserted that, notwithstanding the fact that 35 to 40 people—that is, detainees—had actually been involved in that rebellion, seven had been singled out by the department and six of those had been seized by police and security guards at the Maribyrnong Detention Centre and had been taken to Port Phillip Prison. They are still in Port Phillip Prison, as far as I am aware, and they have not been charged with any offences. Mr Benbrika went on to assert that these people had been assaulted by the security people in the Maribyrnong Detention Centre and by police. They had been assaulted physically—this is the claim that was made.

I immediately contacted the office of Mr Farmer, the Secretary of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, and one of his senior lieutenants spoke to me about the matter. I was not satisfied, however, with the explanation that was given. I did tell him that I would go down on the Friday—that was the next day—to visit the people. He did assure me that no-one had been injured and that only one person had a slight scratch on their forehead. When I went to visit these six people at the Port Phillip Prison I discovered a different story. In fact, one had virtually had his arm broken—not quite broken but severely contorted—and he had been in hospital at the prison for a number of days. Several others had severe bruising in different parts of their bodies. The claim that these people had not been assaulted appears, on that evidence, to be false, unless there is some other explanation for these bruises. This situation gave me great concern and, on the basis of that, I raised the matter with the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Commonwealth Ombudsman undertook to hold an inquiry into the matter. That inquiry has proceeded apace, and is still proceeding.

I want to just indicate, because the time is running out, that there are a number of other very serious aspects to this issue. For example, why was it that 35 to 40 people felt so aggrieved that they actually rebelled in the detention centre? I have put two questions to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs on this matter—question Nos 838 and 839—and I would ask members to have a look at those questions and to see what can be done. I am looking forward to the answers from the minister. I am also looking forward to the response of the Ombudsman, as is the UNHCR and Amnesty International—both bodies have had the matter raised with them. We are looking forward to getting real answers to what has happened in relation to this extremely serious question with respect to the people at the Maribyrnong Detention Centre. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As honourable members would know and as many in the community would know, areas of my electorate of Robertson were devastated by the outbreak of newcastle disease amongst the chicken industry at Mangrove Mountain on 1 April—that was the day that it was first identified this year. It resulted in the slaughter of some two million chickens and the devastation of the entire industry in the Mangrove Mountain area. More importantly, it resulted in devastation and financial difficulty for many families in that area.

speech.para: At that time, people from all over New South Wales, the state government and the federal government, all rushed to help the communities of Mangrove Mountain. It was a great effort by all the volunteers and government officials. The federal government arranged for some ex gratia payments to enable those families to at least feed their children, put food on the table, and pay some of the basic bills, because their entire livelihoods had been destroyed by an unexpected and unanticipated event.

There appears to be a view in the community that this crisis is over, that the disease has been eradicated. But the crisis is not over, not for these families on Mangrove Mountain. While some of the farms are now beginning to slowly be restocked, many of them, particularly those farms that are under contract or work with the Ingham's company, have not been restocked. They hope to be restocked within a few weeks, but it then takes 16 weeks for these young chickens to be fully grown, and, more importantly, produce an income for those farmers. That will be in four or five months time.

The ex gratia payments that the federal government has contributed, some $250,000, have now ceased because the quarantine restrictions have been lifted. These farmers are now left in limbo for the next four or five months, and it is causing a great deal of heartache in the community.

I spoke only this morning to Dr Joanne Sillance, the Executive Director of the Australian Chicken Growers Association. She was very distressed by the plight of some of these farmers. She said to me, `Jim, how do you think I feel when I have to look these farmers in the eye and tell them that they are not going to have any income for at least the next four or five months?' That was the difficulty. That statement really affected me because these people are my friends as well. I am part of their community and, when they hurt, I hurt.

I appeal to the federal government to look at the proposal that I put forward, in conjunction with Dr Joanne Sillance, to allow those ex gratia payments to continue for some time, not as a gift, not as a hand-out—these people do not want hand-outs—but as a small, interest free loan to enable them to have money to put food on the table for their children for the next three or four months at least, until we can get this industry back on its feet.

There is an exceptional circumstances application which the federal government is looking at. But exceptional circumstances only come into operation when farmers have had a significant downturn in their income for more than 12 months. The Mangrove Mountain people do not fit into that criterion at this stage. I believe that they will. I believe that they will have a significant downturn in their industry and their income for much more than 12 months. But, at this stage, that application has been laid aside for two months until we can better assess the effect on the industry.

There is also a Premier's fund. I understand the New South Wales government offers low interest loans to assist farmers at this stage. But I also understand that that is assets tested. I would appeal to the New South Wales government, and in particular to the New South Wales minister, Mr Amery, to look at the Premier's fund to see where they can assist.

I was very disappointed in a press release that Mr Amery put out on 6 August where he claimed that the federal government was refusing the exceptional circumstances application. He knows that the application did not meet the criterion which all state and federal government ministers had agreed to. He knows that it has only been put aside to further increase the chances of that exceptional circumstances application being successful.

I appeal to the government, and to everyone that is involved in this crisis, to understand that the crisis is not over, that the families are still suffering, and that we need to do much, much more to ensure that those families are looked after in this crisis. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to make a few more comments about the issue that I raised before which has to do with the Maribyrnong Detention Centre. As I mentioned, I put two questions on notice to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, but I am very concerned about the conditions in the centre and the reasons why the people rebelled in the centre. It should be brought to the attention of the House that 55 persons signed a letter to Amnesty International on 15 July, one week before this rebellion, protesting about the conditions at the centre. The minister has to look into this. I understand that there is an internal inquiry by the department—
—Order! The time allowed for the debate has expired.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business: Australian Research Strategies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 574)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 31 March 1999:

question.para: Has he or his Department engaged Australasian Research Strategies to conduct research; if so, (a) what matters are to be, or were, canvassed in the research, (b) who has received a copy of the research report, (c) is the report available to the public; if so, at what cost, (d) was the research put to tender; if so, (i) what criteria and process were used to select the successful tender and (ii) was the cheapest tender accepted, (e) did any of the States or Territories contribute to the cost of the research, (f) what was the cost to the Commonwealth and (g) what percentage of the cost was borne by the Commonwealth and each of the contributing States and Territories.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Department, on behalf of a number of Labour Ministers' Council (LMC) governments engaged Australasian Research Strategies on 22 May 1998 to undertake research on attitudes to workplace reform.
(a) The project is designed to obtain information on the drivers behind attitudes to workplace reform.
(b) The Department received copies of the research report and has provided copies to the governments participating in Phase 2 of the project.

(c) The Minister publicly released summary findings of the first and second stages of the research on 17 February 1999. A seminar to release the research results from these stages was held on 3 May 1999, involving business, academic and media representatives. The report is available free of charge.
(d) The company was selected by participating governments of LMC from a panel of 34 researchers established by the Department on behalf of LMC through open advertisement in late 1997 because:
- of the panel members, ARS was the only researcher to provide a fully detailed proposal for values research; and

- it is the sole supplier in Australia of a qualitative research methodology, VISTATM values research methodology. This methodology was chosen because it has been used successfully internationally, including by a number of governments, to improve understanding of the drivers behind public attitudes.
(e) Yes.
(f) To date of the $260,890 paid for the completed Phases I and II of the project, the cost to the Commonwealth was $185,667.50.

(g) The percentage of the cost to the Commonwealth for Phases I and II was 71 per cent with the remaining 29 per cent being contributed by the participating State and Territory Governments. These State and Territory Governments have not agreed to be identified so it is not possible to provide information about each of their contributions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small business, upon notice, on 21 June 1999:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 24 (Hansard , 9 February 1999, page 2264) in which he referred to positive discrimination measures within the internal management practices of his Department, for those measures which are available to and impact on the general public (a) what measures has the Department implemented which could be categorised as positive discrimination, that is, providing preference to certain citizens on the basis of their gender, sexuality, age, race, place of birth or some other personal characteristic, and (b) what are the details and funding commitments in each case.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has implemented a number of measures which could be categorised as positive discrimination, in the sense of active encouragement of desirable policy outcomes.

These measures are encompassed in the department's Workplace Diversity Strategy. In very broad terms the strategy seeks to build an inclusive environment in which the diverse skills, cultural perspectives and backgrounds of departmental staff are valued. The Strategy also emphasises employment equity, which, among other things, ensures that employment decisions are based on merit. The Strategy has been developed in accordance with Government policy and the requirement of the Public Service Act.

A key initiative under the Workplace Diversity Strategy is the development and implementation of an Indigenous Australian Recruitment and Career Development Strategy for the department (the Strategy was launched in June 1999). This strategy aims to increase the number of Indigenous Australian staff in the department through recruitment and retention strategies and to improve the representation of Indigenous Australian staff in professional, technical and management positions.
Specific initiatives implemented in accordance with this Strategy include:
. employing Indigenous Australian cadets whereby the department contributes to the cost of university study and provides vacation work placements for cadets; and
. offering study programs specifically targeted at Indigenous Australian staff, ie the Aboriginal Undergraduate Study Awards (AUSA) and the Aboriginal Staff Sponsorship Program (ASSP).

The department also participates in Australian Public Service (APS) development programs targeted at women. For instance, the department sponsors staff on the Senior Women in Management program (SWIM). SWIM is aimed at women senior officers in the department and offers placements in other agencies and organisations plus course work. In addition, the department will next year encourage staff to participate in Springboard, a development program aimed at women in APS 1-4 classifications.

As mentioned in response to the honourable member's previous question, the other area of positive discrimination occurs in relation to Recruitment Services Australia (RSA). The department has responsibility for RSA which administers the Indigenous Australian test for recruitment to designated positions and the Graduate Administrative Assistant Program for the APS, which has special eligibility criteria for Indigenous Australian applicants.

(b) Currently the department sponsors two Indigenous Australian cadets and four AUSA recipients. For the next calendar year the department intends engaging an additional eight cadets and offering one place under the ASSP. The combined total commitment for 1999-2000 is $409,000.

Funding for the SWIM program for 1999-2000 (one participant for the remainder of 1999 and two in 2000) is $165,000. Costs associated with participation in the Springboard program will be dependent on number of participants sponsored by the department.

Funding for the Indigenous Australian recruitment test is on a fee for service basis. Departments using the services of the RSA are charged a fee of $325 per placed applicant. The department is provided with a loan from the Department of Finance and Administration, which is now approximately $890,000, to administer the centralised recruitment program, which includes the Indigenous Australian recruitment program.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Members question:

answer.para: The Family and Community Services portfolio has a number of income support programs. Some of these programs have eligibility requirements that include age or gender qualifications. In addition, within the range of programs funded by the Department of Family and Community Services, some funding is provided for groups that serve a specific section of the community. However, it is not considered that these programs represent positive discrimination in the sense implied in the honourable member's question.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 22 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say what is the exact nature of the covenant placed upon the site of Shepherd's Hill Cottage in Newcastle.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to a use or proposed use of the site which may contravene the covenant.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The covenants placed upon the Shepherd's Hill Cottage site are as follows:

(a) The Transferee shall not demolish, damage, alter or change the essential historic character of the said land and the improvements thereon or permit same and shall maintain the land and the improvements thereon in good order and condition having regard to their essential historic character;

(b) The transferee shall not use or permit to be used the land and any improvements thereon for any purposes other than as an historical and recreational site provided however that the cottage on the said land (being the cottage known as "No. 45 The Terrace, Shepherds Hill"), may be occupied as a home for an artist-in-residence or for any similar purposes not inconsistent with the said historical character;
(c) The transferee shall not permit any new buildings or structures to be erected on the said land which adversely affects the historic character of the cottage, battery or King Edward Park; and
(d) These covenants shall run with the land.

(2) Mr Kerry Hickey, MP, Member for Cessnock, recently wrote to me advising that the Newcastle City Council is preparing to obtain consent from the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation to lease Shepherd's Hill cottage to the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol (RVCP). Mr Hickey suggests that this proposed usage may contravene the covenant.

Officers of my Department have confirmed with the Newcastle City Council that the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation has given in principle agreement to such a proposal, primarily to enable the RVCP to set up a marine base and thereby overcome radio coverage problems in the area.

The Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) has advised my Department that, on the basis of the available information, the use of the site by the RVCP would not be inconsistent with its historic character. In relation to the fitting out of a room for radio communications and providing bathroom and kitchen facilities, however, the AHC has advised that the extent of such work would need to be assessed against the impact that these proposals would have on the significance of the Shepherd's Hill Cottage. Accordingly, I have directed my Department to ascertain the full details of the scope of the proposed work and request the AHC to assess their impact on heritage values as soon as possible.
